title: 109_s2148
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor Study Act of 2005" defines key terms like "Corridor" and "Secretary" and outlines the study area for the Chattahoochee National Heritage Corridor. The Secretary, in consultation with various organizations, will conduct a study to assess the suitability of designating the Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor. The study area includes cities, towns, and military bases in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River Basin. The cities, towns, and military bases in Alabama and counties in the State of Alabama are being considered for designation in the Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor study. The study for the Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor includes areas in Georgia such as Fort Gaines, Bluffton, Bainbridge, and others, as well as counties in Georgia like Troup, Muscogee, and Stewart. It also considers areas in Alabama or Georgia with similar heritage aspects. The study will analyze natural, historic, and cultural resources in the designated areas. The Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor has natural, historic, and cultural resources that represent distinctive aspects of the United States' heritage, reflecting traditions and beliefs valuable to the country. It offers opportunities for conservation, recreation, and education. The Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor offers outstanding recreational and educational opportunities, contains important resources supporting identified themes, involves various stakeholders in planning and financial roles, and has a potential management entity for partnership. The Chattahoochee Trace National Heritage Corridor involves partnerships with stakeholders to develop the corridor and has a boundary map supported by the public. The Secretary is required to submit a report to the House of Representatives and Senate committees within three years of funding allocation, detailing the study's findings, conclusions, and recommendations.
